The Bush Administration's reaction to the events in the Soviet Union has been cautious, reflecting both its uncertainty over the outcome and its efforts to fight plans for more cuts in military spending.

A cut in NATO and Soviet aircraft in Europe has been proposed by the U.S. Combined with the President's initiative to cut troops in Europe, the plan is aimed at speeding completion of a conventional arms treaty.

East Germany's power-sharing pact between Prime Minister Hans Modrow and the opposition was formalized by the Parliament, which also voted to add eight Cabinet members from the opposition to the Government.

The Czechoslovak secret police no longer spies on the nation's citizens. With hundreds of workers at the force's headquarters sent home, Government officials offered a reassuring tour of its empty offices.

South Africa's Conservative Party, furious that President F. W. de Klerk legalized the African National Congress and promised to free Nelson Mandela, said it will fiercly oppose the plan.
Anti-apartheid violence continues in South Africa
South Korea's strife-weary leaders say they would transform their government into one like Japan's, where a single, conservative party domi-nates a parliamentary-style system.

The laundering of money in Panama from the sale of illicit drugs is likely to continue unabated, American officials say, because the new Government has resisted pressure to reform its banking laws.
Costa Rica's newly elected President is Rafael Calderon, a critic of President Oscar Arias's Central American peace efforts. He defeated Carlos Manuel Castillo, the candidate from Mr. Arias's party.

An Islamic organization in Lebanon affliated with the coalition Islamic Holy War has claimed responsibility for the attack on a tour bus in Egypt, saying it opposes current Middle East peace efforts as well as the influx of Soviet Jews.
Amid ethnic stife, Turkey recalls its own ethnic conflicts

Former President Ronald Reagan, citing executive privilege, refused to turn over excerpts of his diaries to John Poindexter, who says they will show that Mr. Reagan authorized his actions in the Iran-contra affair.

A fifth former H.U.D. official has refused to testify before a House subcommittee investigating abuse in the agency during the Reagan Administration, invoking Fifth Amendment protections against self-incrimination.
The threat of global warming warrants a cautious response, President Bush said. His speech pleased Administration officials who advocate a deliberate policy but disappointed environmentalists.

Notre Dame struck a deal with NBC to give the television network exclusive rights to all its home football games for five years. By doing so, Notre Dame breaks ranks with other major universities on television contracts.
The Harvard Law Review elected Barack Obama as its president. He is the first black to hold the post in the review's 104-year history.
Thieves willing to kill for clothes have slain four men in Chicago since last fall in confrontations over fashionable athletic jackets, which cost between $90 and $200.

The trial of a Federal judge began in San Francisco with jury selection. Robert Aguilar is the first Federal judge to be tried for violating the Federal racketeering statute through his alleged involvement with two convicted felons.
American attitudes toward Japan and the Japanese have become increasingly negative, a new poll shows. Analysts say the rise is the result of Japanese investments and the end of the cold war.

An inquiry into the Rev. Bruce Ritter and allegations that he provided gifts in return for sexual favors has eroded support for Covenant House, the nation's largest shelter for runaway youngsters, which he founded.
Minimal raises for city workers this year, with promises of larger raises in the future, are being considered by New York City officials.
New Jersey faces a budget deficit of more than $550 million, the Florio Administration said. The Governor is said to be contemplating tax increases despite his campaign pledge that none were needed.
The state police chief in New Jersey, Clinton Pagano, was reassigned by Gov. Jim Florio. Mr. Pagano, who will now head the Division of Motor Vehicles, was replaced by a deputy, Justin Dintino.
The nation's newest fighting ship, the guided-missle cruiser Normandy, will replace the Iowa as the flagship of the Navy group to be based at Stapleton, S.I.
